Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. Repetitive DNA makes up a large fraction of the total DNA in most organisms. Although it has sometimes been called "junk DNA", studies show that repetitive DNA is critical to many processes including how genes are regulated, genome evolution, aging, and disease. Despite its critical role, repetitive DNA is understudied. This is largely because software programs available for studying repetitive DNA can be difficult to use and their performance has not been compared against uniform standards of success. This project aims to address these challenges and simplify the process for scientists to study repetitive DNA using the best available programs. As scientists can better study repetitive DNA and its role in aging, cancer, and other processes affecting human health, society will in turn benefit. This project will place the fellow in an ideal setting for studying repetitive DNA alongside leading experts in the field. The project will also deliver career building opportunities to five students from underrepresented groups by engaging them directly in the research, and will promote mentorship of additional students within the department. Added diversity of individuals in science improves the quality of scientific research, and benefits society as privilege gaps close and individuals of all backgrounds have access to their desired careers.

The applicant will build a workflow for benchmarking transposable element (TE) annotation programs against well-studied animal, plant, and fungus model species. Using simulated and empirical datasets generated from these models, the applicant will evaluate a panel of available TE annotation programs to measure their effectiveness at annotating TE insertions across model species, and across TE families. Following performance testing, the best-performing programs will be wrapped into a pipeline designed to be portable and easily expandable. The applicant will demonstrate the utility of this pipeline by profiling repetitive DNA in a diverse family of beetles (Carabidae) to test hypotheses of transposon biology in the group. Students mentored under the project will be trained in basic command-line and bioinformatic skills, as well as molecular bench work including DNA extraction and library preparation. The fellow will receive training in computational biology, computer programming, and transposon biology, as well as opportunities to hone mentoring skills.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

Understanding how genomes evolve is fundamental to biological research and human health. In most organisms, large fractions of the genome are made up of repetitive DNA elements. These repetitive elements have a major impact on genome evolution; however, they have been difficult to study historically and therefore receive less research attention than unique DNA sequences (such as genes), which are easier to study using traditional methods. This project aimed to simplify the study of repetitive DNA elements through development of new software tools that can be applied to any organism for which DNA sequences are available. Another aim was to demonstrate the usefulness of the new tools in a diverse group of beetles for which little is known about their repetitive DNA. The project also aimed to serve as a vehicle for upward mobility of trainees (undergraduate and high school students) through mentorship and outreach, with a focus on students historically underrepresented in science.

During this project, the awardee worked alongside undergraduate trainees to develop a software pipeline called RepeatProfiler – a new tool for studying repetitive DNA elements in any organism. The tool provides new ways to analyze patterns of repetitive DNA elements using data sources that are inexpensive to generate. RepeatProfiler has been well-received by the community and in the months since publication already has well over 100 unique users. The awardee and collaborators demonstrated the usefulness of the tool through new studies on repetitive DNA in ground beetles. By studying several species that previously showed clues of interesting repetitive DNA evolution, the awardee used RepeatProfiler to present new evidence that rapid repeat evolution in these beetles is likely caused by an interaction between transposable elements and ribosomal DNA, two classes of repetitive elements that are present in all plants, animals, and fungi. These findings led to a new hypothesis that can explain past observations of rapid genome evolution in many other organisms. Testing this exciting hypothesis will form much of the basis of the awardee’s research in coming years. During the project, the awardee also made new discoveries in the field of repetitive DNA evolution through other studies in fruit flies, beetles, and caddisflies. The project in fruit flies studied the rapid evolution of repetitive elements called satellite DNA with unprecedented detail in order to give new insights on how satellite DNAs change their abundance and position in genomes. The studies in beetles and caddisflies were the first to map patterns of repetitive DNA in organisms for which we had little or no prior knowledge of how repetitive elements contribute to their genome evolution. Together these projects contribute to the awardee’s career goal to use diverse insect groups as models to uncover fundamental rules of life, with emphasis on how repetitive elements shape the evolution of genomes and species. 

Broader impacts:

This fellowship brought the awardee to an institution and laboratory ideally suited to expand his computational training and connect him to a network of experts in the field of genome evolution and repetitive DNA. With this training and research environment the awardee was able to build new research collaborations with researchers spanning five institutions that led to several recently published and ongoing projects. The awardee recently accepted a job offer as a tenure-track professor, and the diverse training provided by this fellowship was fundamental to that successful application. The awardee worked to provide similar training and networking opportunities to trainees recruited to fellowship-related projects. Four undergraduate trainees are authors on recently published papers, or papers nearing submission. All four were supported in subsequent transitions to their next training or employment opportunity. The awardee worked with his mentor to strengthen the relationship between the lab/department and institutions on campus that serve underrepresented students. During the fellowship, the lab provided deep mentorship to two students from underrepresented groups. One went on to graduate school, and the other was recently accepted to dental school and is a coauthor on a manuscript nearing publication. The awardee also worked to strengthen connections between the Biology Department and the Upward Bound program that supports local high school students from underrepresented groups. He led annual workshops that brought Upward Bound students to the Biology department where they explored the natural world and learned about careers in biology. The awardee also spent over 100 hours learning about the underlying causes of opportunity gaps for minority groups in academia and society through classic and contemporary literature, and many additional hours working to support initiatives within the department that increase equity, inclusion and diversity. In the weeks following the fellowship the awardee began mentorship of four additional students on projects that began during the fellowship, and will continue to prioritize access and upward mobility of diverse trainees moving forward in his career.
